content:
Nice clash, a touch on the hard side since you have to do shadok conversion both ways AND solve the 'minimum coins'/'coin change' problem in the same clash.

My only actual issue though, is that in my clash I found that clashers could get 50% by just submitting:
console.log(readline().split(" ")[0])
because the first two validators' answer is simply the first shadok word in the input (it actually gets 75% on the test cases).

It would be good to add more tests/validators to avoid this easy way to get a high percentage without coding anything.

I was the only person to solve it in my clash (Shortest mode). But two clashers got 50% with <40 character code. The other two clashers got 0%. https://www.codingame.com/clashofcode/clash/report/411966321766fcd05a408b410cbd18e843d1ced
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

After spending full 15 minutes trying to solve this AND reading your solution I still don't understand what the question is. Could you reword the statement to be clearer about what "minimal number of pumps" means?
Okay for the translation base-4 langage, but not clear about "The minimal number of pumps needed to seat all shadoks." ... and i still don't understand clearly even with the solution

100% on all tests
75% on validators
It takes a little effort to make your validators such that they don't differ much from the tests. 
The point of having validators that are different from the tests is to prevent hardcoding, NOT to prevent debugging. If there are cases covered in validators that aren't in the tests, one can't check for that.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: C’est fun mais semble un peut difficile pour un clash

Wrote a solution that passes the tests, but not sure to cover all optimal cases.
At least I found some inspiration for my variables names :-)
« S’il n’y a pas de solution, c’est qu’il n’y a pas de problème. »
Very nice, I like it but seem too difficult to be on a clash especially with finding the optimal solution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good reference ! 
allways tricky to count in another base

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like the reference to the shadoks :) 
There are many steps for a clash of code (at least 3: decode, compute, encode) but I think it's enjoyable.

In the Goal section, please add a brief explanation using the first example, because it may not be clear enough. You may show just the decimal equivalents of the numbers and skip calculations so that you do not give away too many hints. Thanks.

Is that what you had in mind? 

BTW, I was concerned that there might already be some similar CoC, but don't know how I could search for them. Do you have some pointers?

In practice, the optimal solution can be found in a greedy way, simply iteratively and not at once for the number wanted... 

But I agree that most clashes are easier, though the passing criteria is "feasible within 5' " which I feel like this one definitely is. It's just not a 30" one ^^

import sys

shadoks = input().split()
print(shadoks, file = sys.stderr)

gabuzomeu = ["ga", "bu", "zo", "meu"]

nb_shadoks = 0
for power, digit in enumerate(reversed(shadoks)):
    nb_shadoks += gabuzomeu.index(digit) * 4**power

zobubuga = {7:0, 5:0, 1:0}
for pump_size in zobubuga.keys():
    zobubuga[pump_size] +=  nb_shadoks // pump_size
    nb_shadoks = nb_shadoks % pump_size

# try to find optimal:
if zobubuga[7] >= 1 and zobubuga[1] == 3:
    zobubuga[7] -=1
    zobubuga[5] += 2
    zobubuga[1] = 0

nb_pumps = sum(zobubuga.values())

if nb_pumps == 0:
    print("ga")
    exit()

zobuga = ""
leading_ga = True
for i in reversed(range(5)):
    zoga = f"{gabuzomeu[nb_pumps // 4**i]} "
    if zoga != "ga " or not leading_ga:
        zobuga += zoga
        leading_ga = False
    nb_pumps = nb_pumps % 4**i
print(zobuga[0:-1])

Could you tell me which validator failed/what your approach was? 

As you can guess, I wasn’t the only one who didn’t have the issue and the only one I could see as « more complex » would be jumping from 100 to 1000 shadoks, though we are still extremely far from any kind of variable limits :/

Not sure how it will impact it (what with it already being approved), but would the following addendum (before the note) help? 

"As an example, you could seat 12 shadoks on: 
- 1 pump of 7 and one of 5 (total of 2 pumps)
- 2 pumps of 5 and 2 of 1 (total of 4 pumps)
- 1 pump of 7 and 5 of 1 (total of 6 pumps)
- 1 pump of 5 and 7 of 1 (total of 8 pumps)
- 12 pumps of 1 (total of 12 pumps). 

Therefore, the answer would be the smallest of all those totals, so here 2."

Not sure how it will impact it (what with it already being approved), but I can try. Would the following addendum (before the note) be better? 

"As an example, you could seat 12 shadoks on: 
- 1 pump of 7 and one of 5 (total of 2 pumps)
- 2 pumps of 5 and 2 of 1 (total of 4 pumps)
- 1 pump of 7 and 5 of 1 (total of 6 pumps)
- 1 pump of 5 and 7 of 1 (total of 8 pumps)
- 12 pumps of 1 (total of 12 pumps). 

Therefore, the answer would be the smallest of all those totals, so here 2."
Oh I understand now! Mentioning that all seats must be filled would already help a lot, although an example doesn't hurt either.
I have updated it with both, not sure how it will be taken into account, though

What about replacing "he has a set of pumps that can seat each 1, 5 or 7 shadoks."
By "a pump is a group of 1,5 or 7 shadocks" ?
this is more clear that we have to group them
I mean, reading less is good cause to make a converter for base4 then translating then going back is already taking time

because it would ruin the reference, and I don't see the added value? 

By saying that it SEATS 1-7 shadoks, isn't it clear that you need that many shadoks to operate it?

I just had the same issue (100% on tests, 75% on validators) and it was the 1000 shadoks validator.
Basically that validator is hard enough that if you try the brute force method (iterating through a combination of all possible groups of 1, 5 and 7 shadoks and testing for the ones that give exactly n shadoks in total i.e. [*0...n].product([*0..n/5],[*0..n/7])) ends up becoming too large a space and doesn't output an answer.

It's good to not jump so far in terms of difficulty between test cases and validators. If the final test case was 939 for example, then I would have realised I needed to optimise and not clicked submit.

Not exactly what I had in mind, but your way is better, so no complaints there :)

Actually there are some shadok-themed clashes, but I think yours may not be that similar? Not sure how others view it though. You can search approved clashes here:
https://eulerschezahl.herokuapp.com/codingame/puzzles/

Thanks! 

I indeed think mine is not that similar, due to the added step of finding the right number of pumps (I thought just translating would be FAR too simple, but that adding the pump counting would take it to just the right level to not be 100% obvious but stay easy).
